sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But the user and the thing he uses are different, are they not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For instance, I suppose a shoemaker uses a round tool, and a square one, and others, when he cuts.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the cutter and user is quite different from what he uses in cutting?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And in the same way what the harper uses in harping will be different from the harper himself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

p.#text:
Well then, that is what I was asking just nowwhether the user
and what he uses are always, in your opinion, two different things.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what are we to say of the shoemaker?  Does he cut with his tools only, or with his hands as well?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: With his hands as well.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So he uses these also?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does he use his eyes, too, in his shoe-making?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we admit that the user and what he uses are different things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

p.#text:
Then the shoemaker and the harper are different from
the hands and eyes that they use for their work?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And man uses his whole body too?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we said that the user and what he uses are different?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So man is different from his own body?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then whatever is man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Oh, but you canthat he is the user of the body.

p.#text: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the user of it must be the soul?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And ruler?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now, here is a remark from which no one, I think, can dissent.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That man must be one of three things.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What things?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Soul, body, or both together as one whole.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Very well.

p.#text: But yet we have admitted that what actually rules the body is man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We have.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And does the body rule itself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because we have said that it is ruled.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then that cannot be what we are seeking.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, does the combination of the two rule the body, so that we are to regard this as man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Perhaps it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The unlikeliest thing in the world:  for if one of the two does not share in the rule, it is quite inconceivable that the combination of the two can be ruling.

p.#text: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But since neither the body nor the combination of the two is man, we are reduced, I suppose, to this:  either man is nothing at all, or if something, he turns out to be nothing else than soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Precisely so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, do you require some yet clearer proof that the soul is man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I assure you:  I think it is amply proved.

p.#text:
And if it is tolerably, though not exactly, we are content;  exact knowledge will be ours later,
when we have discovered the thing that we passed over just now because it would involve much consideration.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is that?

note.#text: Cf. .

p.#text: The point suggested in that remark a moment ago, that we should first consider the same-in-itself;  but so far, instead of the same, we have been considering what each single thing is in itself.  And perhaps we shall be satisfied with that:  for surely we cannot say that anything has more absolute possession of ourselves than the soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it is proper to take the view that you and I are conversing with each other, while we make use of words, by intercourse of soul with soul?

p.#text: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, that is just what we suggested a little while agothat Socrates, in using words to talk with Alcibiades, is holding speech, not with your face, it would seem, but with Alcibiadesthat is, with his soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I believe so.

p.#text: Then he who enjoins a knowledge of oneself bids us become acquainted with the soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And anyone who gets to know something belonging to the body knows the things that are his, but not himself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then no physician, in so far as he is a physician, knows himself, nor does any trainer, in so far as he is a trainer.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems not.

p.#text:
And farmers, and craftsmen generally, are far from knowing themselves.  For these people, it would seem, do not even know their own things, but only things still more remote than their own things, in respect of the arts which they follow;  since they know
but the things of the body, with which it is tended.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So if knowing oneself is temperance, none of these people is temperate in respect of his art.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: None, I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that is why these arts are held to be sordid, and no acquirements for a good man.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then once again, whoever tends his body tends his own things, but not himself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It looks rather like it.

p.#text:
But whoever tends his money tends neither himself nor
his own things, but only things yet more remote than his own things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So that the money-maker has ceased to do his own business.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Correct.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if anyone is found to be a lover of Alcibiades' body, he has fallen in love, not with Alcibiades, but with something belonging to Alcibiades?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Your lover is rather he who loves your soul?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: He must be, apparently, by our argument.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And he who loves your body quits you, and is gone, as soon as its bloom is over?

p.#text: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whereas he who loves your soul will not quit you so long as it makes for what is better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I am he who does not quit you, but remains with you when your body's prime is over, and the rest have departed.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, and I am glad of it, Socrates, and hope you will not go.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you must endeavor to be as handsome as you can.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, I shall endeavor.

p.#text:
You see how you stand:  Alcibiades,
the son of Cleinias, it seems, neither had nor has any lover except one only, and that a cherished one, Socrates, the son of Sophroniscus and Phaenarete.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you said that I only just anticipated you in coming to you, for otherwise you would have come to me first for the purpose of inquiring why I am the only one who does not leave you?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, that was so.

p.#text:
Then the reason was that I was the only lover of you, whereas the rest were lovers of what is yours;  and that is losing its charm,
    while you are beginning to bloom.  So now, if you are not blighted and deformed by the Athenian people, I shall never forsake you.  For my chiefest fear is of your being blighted by becoming a lover of the people, since many a good Athenian has come to that ere now.  For fair of face is   but you should get a view of it stripped:  so take the precaution that I recommend.
What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Exercise yourself first, my wonderful friend, in learning what you ought to know before entering on politics;  you must wait till you have learnt, in order that you may be armed with an antidote and so come to no harm.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Your advice seems to me good, Socrates;  but try to explain in what way we can take pains over ourselves.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, we have made one step in advance;  for there is a pretty fair agreement now as to what we are, whereas we were afraid we might fail of this and take pains, without knowing it, over something other than ourselves.

p.#text: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the next step, we see, is to take care of the soul, and look to that.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: While handing over to others the care of our bodies and our coffers.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then how shall we obtain the most certain knowledge of it?  For if we know that, it seems we shall know ourselves also.  In Heaven's name, do we fail to comprehend the wise words of the Delphic inscription, which we mentioned just now?

p.#text: With what intent do you say that, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you what I suspect to be the real advice which the inscription gives us.  I rather think there are not many illustrations of it to be found, but only in the case of sight.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Consider in your turn:  suppose that, instead of speaking to a man, it said to the eye of one of us, as a piece of advice See thyself, how should we apprehend the meaning of the admonition?  Would it not be, that the eye should look at that by looking at which it would see itself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly.

p.#text:
Then let us think what object there is anywhere, by looking at which
we can see both it and ourselves.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, clearly, Socrates, mirrors and things of that sort.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Quite right.  And there is also something of that sort in the eye that we see with?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

note.#text: The Greek  and the Latin pupilla both mean little girl or doll, and were used to indicate the dark center of the eye in which a tiny image can be seen reflected.

p.#text:
And have you observed that the face of the person who looks into another's eye is shown in the optic confronting him,
as in a mirror, and we call this the pupil, for in a sort it is an image of the person looking?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then an eye viewing another eye, and looking at the most perfect part of it, the thing wherewith it sees, will thus see itself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

note.#text: i.e. it must look at the pupil of a man's eye, or at what is comparable to that perfect part in other things.

p.#text: But if it looks at any other thing in man or at anything in nature but what resembles this, it will not see itself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if an eye is to see itself, it must look at an eye, and at that region of the eye in which the virtue of an eye is found to occur;  and this, I presume, is sight.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if the soul too, my dear Alcibiades, is to know herself, she must surely look at a soul, and especially at that region of it in which occurs the virtue of a soulwisdom, and at any other part of a soul which resembles this?

p.#text: I agree, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can we find any part of the soul that we can call more divine than this, which is the seat of knowledge and thought?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We cannot.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then this part of her resembles God, and whoever looks at this, and comes to know all that is divine, will gain thereby the best knowledge of himself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

note.#text: Above, .

p.#text: And self-knowledge we admitted to be temperance.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So if we have no knowledge of ourselves and no temperance, shall we be able to know our own belongings, good or evil?

p.#text: How can that be, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For I expect it seems impossible to you that without knowing Alcibiades you should know that the belongings of Alcibiades are in fact his.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Impossible indeed, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor could we know that our belongings are ours if we did not even know ourselves?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How could we?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so, if we did not so much as know our belongings, we could not know the belongings of our belongings either?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently not.

p.#text:
Then we were not quite correct in admitting just now that there are people who, without knowing themselves, know their belongings, while others know their belongings' belongings.  For it seems to be the function of one man and one art to discern all three
himself, his belongings, and the belongings of his belongings.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It looks like it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And anyone who is ignorant of his belongings will be similarly ignorant, I suppose, of the belongings of others.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if ignorant of others' affairs, he will be ignorant also of the affairs of states.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: He must be.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then such a man can never be a statesman.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

p.#text: No, nor an economist either.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor will he know what he is doing.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And will not he who does not know make mistakes?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when he makes mistakes, will he not do ill both in private and in public?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And doing ill he will be wretched?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, very.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what of those for whom he is doing so?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: They will be wretched also.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is impossible to be happy if one is not temperate and good.

p.#text: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So it is the bad men who are wretched.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, very.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And hence it is not he who has made himself rich that is relieved of wretchedness, but he who has made himself temperate.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So it is not walls or warships or arsenals that cities need, Alcibiades, if they are to be happy, nor numbers, nor size, without virtue.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if you are to manage the city's affairs properly and honorably, you must impart virtue to the citizens.

p.#text: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But could one possibly impart a thing that one had not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How, indeed?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you or anyone else who is to be governor and curator, not merely of himself and his belongings in private, but of the state and its affairs, must first acquire virtue himself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence it is not licence or authority for doing what one pleases that you have to secure to yourself or the state, but justice and temperance.

p.#text: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For you and the state, if you act justly and temperately, will act so as to please God.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Naturally.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And, as we were saying in what went before, you will act with your eyes turned on what is divine and bright.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, and looking thereon you will behold and know both yourselves and your good.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so you will act aright and well?

p.#text: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, if you act in this way, I am ready to warrant that you must be happy.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: And I can rely on your warranty.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if you act unjustly, with your eyes on the godless and dark, the probability is that your acts will resemble these through your ignorance of yourselves.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is probable.

p.#text:
For if a man, my dear Alcibiades, is at liberty to do what he pleases, but is lacking in mind, what is the probable result to him personally, or to the state as well?  For instance, if he is sick and at liberty to do what he pleaseswithout a medical mind,
but with a despot's power which prevents anyone from even reproving himwhat will be the result?  Will not his health, in all likelihood, be shattered?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Again, in a ship, if a man were at liberty to do what he chose, but were devoid of mind and excellence in navigation, do you perceive what must happen to him and his fellow-sailors?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do:  they must all perish.

p.#text:
And in just the same way, if a state, or any office or authority, is lacking in excellence or virtue,
it will be overtaken by failure?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is not despotic power, my admirable Alcibiades, that you ought to secure either to yourself or to the state, if you would be happy, but virtue.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And before getting virtue, to be governed by a superior is better than to govern, for a man as well as a child.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the better is also nobler?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the nobler more becoming?

p.#text: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it becomes a bad man to be a slave, since it is better.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So vice is a thing that becomes a slave.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And virtue becomes a free man.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we should shun, my good friend, all slavishness?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Most certainly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you now perceive how you stand?  Are you on the side of the free, or not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think I perceive only too clearly.

p.#text: Then do you know how you may escape from the condition in which you now find yourself?  Let us not give it a name, where a handsome person is concerned!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: If it be your wish, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is not well said, Alcibiades.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, what should I say?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If it be God's will.

note.#text: is used here simply in the sense of following about as personal attendant.

p.#text: Then I say it.  And yet I say this besides, that we are like to make a change in our parts, Socrates, so that I shall have yours and you mine.  For from this day onward it must be the case that I am your attendant, and you have me always in attendance on you.

note.#text: It was commonly believed that aged storks were fed by younger storks which they had previously hatched and reared.

p.#text: Ah, generous friend!  So my love will be just like a stork;  for after hatching a winged love in you it is to be cherished in return by its nestling.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, that is the position, and I shall begin here and now to take pains over justice.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I should like to think you will continue to do so;  yet I am apprehensive, not from any distrust of your nature, but in view of the might of the state, lest it overcome both me and you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Alcibiades, are you on your way to offer a prayer to the god?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I am, certainly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You seem, let me say, to have a gloomy look, and to keep your eyes on the ground, as though you were pondering something.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: And what might one ponder, Socrates?

p.#text:
The greatest of questions, Alcibiades,
as I believe.  For tell me, in Heaven's name, do you not think that the gods sometimes grant in part, but in part refuse, what we ask of them in our private and public prayers, and gratify some people, but not others?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do, certainly.

p.#text:
Then you would agree that one should take great precautions against falling unawares into the error of praying for great evils in the belief that they are good, while the gods happen to be disposed to grant freely what one is praying for?  Just as Oedipus,
they say, suddenly prayed that his sons might divide their patrimony with the sword:  it was open to him to pray that his present evils might by some means be averted, but he invoked others in addition to those which he had already.  Wherefore not only were those words of his accomplished, but many other dread results therefrom, which I think there is no need to recount in detail.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But you have instanced a madman, Socrates:  why, do you suppose that anyone could bring himself, while he was in a sound state, to utter such a prayer?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you regard madness as the opposite of wisdom?

p.#text: Certainly I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And there are some men whom you regard as unwise, and others as wise?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come then, let us consider who these people are.  We have admitted that some are unwise, some wise, and others mad.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, we have.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again, there are some in sound health?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: There are.

p.#text: And others also who are in ill-health?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And they are not the same?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are there any others besides, who are found to be in neither state?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For a human being must needs be either sick or not sick.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, do you hold the same view about wisdom and unwisdom?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How do you mean?

p.#text:
Tell me, do you think it is only possible to be either wise or unwise, or is there some third condition between these, which makes
a man neither wise nor unwise?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, there is not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So he must needs be in one or the other of these two conditions.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you remember that you admitted that madness is the opposite of wisdom?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And further, that there is no third condition between these, which makes a man neither wise nor unwise?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, I admitted that.

p.#text: Well now, can there possibly be two opposites of one thing?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it looks as though unwisdom and madness were the same.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So we shall be right, Alcibiades, in saying that all unwise persons are mad;  for example, such of your contemporaries as happen to be unwisesome such there areand of your elders, even:  for tell me, in Heaven's name, do you not think that in our city the wise people are but few, whereas the majority are unwise, and these you call mad?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

p.#text:
Well, do you suppose we could safely live with so many
madmen as our fellow-citizens, and should not long ago have paid the penalty for it in knocks and blows at their hands, and all the usual proceedings of madmen?  Consider now, my wonderful friend, whether the case is not quite different?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, it must be, Socrates.  For it looks as though it were not as I thought.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I think so too.  But there is another way of regarding it.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I wonder what way you mean.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, I will tell you.  We conceive there are some who are sick, do we not?

p.#text: We do, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you believe that a sick man must necessarily have the gout, or a fever, or ophthalmia?  Do you not think that, although he may be afflicted in none of these ways, he may be suffering from some other disease?  For surely there are many of them:  these are not the only ones.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is every ophthalmia, in your opinion, a disease?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is every disease also ophthalmia?

p.#text: No, I should think not:  still, I am in doubt as to my meaning.

foreign.#text: su/n te du/' e)rxome/nw, kai/ te pro\ o(\ tou= e)no/hsen o(/ppws ke/rdos e)/h|

note.#text: Cf.  , if two go along together, then one marks before the other how advantage may be had.

p.#text: Well, if you will attend to me, two together will be searching, and so mayhap we shall find what we seek.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Nay, but I am attending, Socrates, to the best of my power.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we have admitted that while every ophthalmia is a disease, every disease, on the other hand, is not ophthalmia?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We have.

note.#text: here seems to be used for effect produced instead of its usual meaning, fully effecting completion.

p.#text:
And our admission seems to me quite right.  For everyone in a fever is sick, but yet not everyone who is sick has a fever or the gout
or ophthalmia, I take it;  though everything of the sort is a disease, but differsto quote those whom we call doctors  in its manifestation. For they are not all alike, nor of like effect, but each works according to its own faculty, and yet all are diseases.  In the same way, we conceive of some men as artisans, do we not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

p.#text:
That is, cobblers and carpenters and statuaries and a host of others, whom we need not mention in particular;  but any way, they have
their several departments of craft, and all of them are craftsmen;  yet they are not all carpenters or cobblers or statuaries, though these taken together are craftsmen.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

note.#text: has here declined from high-souled or magnanimous to something like Quixotic.
, even in Plato's time, varied between good-hearted and silly.

p.#text:
In the same way, then, have men divided unwisdom also among them, and those who have the largest share of it we call mad, and those who have a little less, dolts and idiots;  though people who prefer to use the mildest language term them sometimes romantic, sometimes simpleminded, or again
innocent, inexperienced, or obtuse;  and many another name will you find if you look for more.  But all these things are unwisdom, though they differ, as we observed that one art or one disease differs from another.  Or how does it strike you?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is my view.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us turn at this point and retrace our steps.  For we said, you know, at the beginning that we must consider who the unwise can be, and who the wise:  for we had admitted that there are such persons, had we not?

p.#text: Yes, we have admitted it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you conceive those to be wise who know what one ought to do and say?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And which are the unwise?  Those who know neither of these things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And those who know neither of these things will say and do unawares what one ought not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

p.#text:
Well, just such a person, as I was saying, Alcibiades,
was Oedipus;  and even in our time you will find many who do the same, not in a fit of anger, as he was:  they think they pray not for something evil, but for something good.  He neither prayed for that, nor thought he did, but there are others who are in the opposite case.  For I imagine that if the god to whom you are now going should appear to you and first ask you, before you made any prayer, whether you would be content to become sovereign of the Athenian state and, on your accounting this as something poor and unimportant, should add and of all the Greeks also;  and if he saw
you were still unsatisfied unless he promised you besides the mastery of all , and should not merely promise you that, but on the self-same day a recognition by all men, if you so desired, of Alcibiades, son of Cleinias, as their sovereignI imagine you would actually depart in a transport of delight, as having secured the greatest of goods.
So would anybody else, I imagine, Socrates, at such a stroke of luck!

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But still you would not wish to sacrifice your life even for the territory and sovereignty of all the Greeks and barbarians together.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I should think not.  How could I, without a prospect of making any use of them?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if you had a prospect of making an evil and injurious use of them?  Not in this case either?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

quote.#text: of a day or two ago,
they themselves by their own presumption
have gotten them more than destined sorrows.

note.#text: This assassination occurred in  B.C., the year of Socrates' death.

l.#text: King Zeus, give unto us what is good, whether we pray or pray not;

l: But what is grievous, even if we pray for it, do thou avert.

p.#text:
So you see it is not safe either to accept casually what one is given, or to pray for one's own advancement, if one is going to be injured in consequence, or deprived of one's life altogether.  Yet we could tell of
    "> many ere now who, having desired sovereignty, and endeavored to secure it, with the idea of working for their good, have lost their lives by plots which their sovereignty has provoked.  And I expect you are not unacquainted with certain events   when Archelaus, the monarch of , was slain by his favorite, who was as much in love with the monarchy as Archelaus was with him, and who killed his lover
with the expectation of being not only the monarch, but also a happy man:  but after holding the monarchy for three or four days he was plotted against by others in his turn, and perished.  You have only to look at some of our own citizensand these are examples that we know, not by hearsay, but by personal observationwho in their time have desired to hold military command
and have obtained it, and see how some to this very day are exiles from our city, while others have lost their lives.  And even those who are deemed to be faring best have not only gone through many dangers and terrors in holding their command, but on returning home have continued to be as sorely besieged by informers as they were by the enemy, so that some of them wished to heaven
that they had been anything but commanders rather than have held such appointments.  Of course, if these dangers and toils were conducive to our advantage, there would be some reason for them;  but the case is quite the contrary.  And you will find it is just the same in regard to children:  some people have been known to pray that they might have them, and when they have got them have fallen into the greatest disasters and pains.  For some have had children that were utterly bad, and have spent their whole lives in repining;  while others, though they had good ones,
were bereft of them by disasters that overtook them, and thus were cast into as great misfortune as the others, and wished that no children at all had been born to them.  But nevertheless, with all this plain evidence, and a great deal more of a similar kind, before men's eyes, it is rare to find anyone who has either declined what was offered to him or, when he was likely to gain something by prayer, refrained from praying.  Most men would not decline the offer of either a monarchy or a generalship
    or any of the various other things which bring with them harm rather than benefit, but would even pray to be granted them in cases where they were lacking:  but after a little while they often change their tune, and retract all their former prayers.  I question therefore if men are not really wrong in blaming the gods as the authors of their ills, when or unwisdom, shall we say?
     It would seem, at any rate, Alcibiades, that one old poet had some wisdom;  for I conceive it was because he had some foolish friends, whom he saw working and praying for things that were not for their advantage, though supposed to be by them, that he made a common prayer on behalf of them all, in terms something like these:
So then, to my mind the poet spoke well and soundly;  but if you have thought of an answer to his words, do not be silent.

It is difficult, Socrates, to gainsay what has been well spoken:  one thing, however, I do observe how many evils are caused to men by ignorance, when, as it seems, we are beguiled by her not only into doing,
butworst of allinto praying to be granted the greatest evils.  Now that is a thing that no one would suppose of himself;  each of us would rather suppose he was competent to pray for his own greatest good, not his greatest evil.  Why, that would seem, in truth, more like some sort of curse than a prayer!

But perhaps, my excellent friend, some person who is wiser than either you or I may say we are wrong to be so free with our abuse of ignorance,
unless we can add that it is ignorance of certain things, and is a good to certain persons in certain conditions, as to those others it is an evil.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How do you mean?  Can there be anything of which it is better for anybody, in any condition whatsoever, to be ignorant than cognizant?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I believe so;  and do not you?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed, upon my word.

p.#text:
But surely I shall not have to tax you with an inclination to commit such an act against your own mother as Orestes and Alcmaeon,
and any others who have followed their example, are said to have committed against theirs.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No unlucky words, in Heaven's name, Socrates!

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, it is not the person who says, Alcibiades, that you would not like to be guilty of such an act, whom you should bid avoid unlucky words, but much rather him who might say the contrary;  since the act seems to you so very dreadful as to be unfit even for such casual mention.  But do you think that Orestes, if he had had all his wits about him and had known what was best for him to do, would have brought himself to commit any act of the sort?

p.#text: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor would anyone else, I imagine.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it seems that ignorance of what is best, and to be ignorant of the best, is a bad thing.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And not only for the person himself, but for everyone else?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

p.#text:
Then let us consider this further case.  Suppose it should quite suddenly occur to your mind that you had better take a dagger and go to the door of Pericles, your own guardian and friend,
and ask if he were at home, with the design of killing just him and no one else, and his servants said he was at home:  now, I do not say you would be inclined to do any such thing, but I suppose, if you are under the impression which at some moment may well be present, surely, to the mind of a man who is ignorant of the bestthat what is really the worst is best at some momentor do you not agree?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

p.#text:
Well then, if you went indoors and saw Pericles himself,
but did not know him, and thought he was somebody else, would you still venture to kill him?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, upon my word, I should think not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For your man was, I presume, not anyone you met, but that particular person whom you wished to kill?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And although you might make a number of attempts, if you always failed to know Pericles when you were about to commit the act, you would never attack him.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

p.#text: Well now, do you suppose that Orestes would ever have attacked his mother if he had similarly failed to know her?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do not think he would.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For presumably he, too, had no intention of killing the first woman he met, or anybody else's mother, but only his own.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then to be ignorant in such matters is better for those who are so disposed and have formed such resolves.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you see that ignorance of certain things is for certain persons in certain states a good, not an evil, as you supposed just now.

p.#text: It seems to be.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if you care to consider the sequel of this, I daresay it will surprise you.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What may that be, Socrates?

p.#text:
I mean that, generally speaking, it rather looks as though the possession of the sciences as a whole, if it does not include possession of the science of the best, will in a few instances help, but in most will harm, the owner.  Consider it this way:  must it not be the case, in your opinion, that when we are about to do or say anything, we first suppose that we know, or do really know, the thing
we so confidently intend to say or do?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think so.

p.#text:
Well, take the orators, for example:  they either know, or think they know, how to advise us on various occasionssome about war and peace, and others about building walls or fitting up harbors; 
and in a word, whatever the city does to another city or within herself, all comes about by the advice of the orators.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then observe the consequence.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: If I am able.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, surely you call men either wise or unwise?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the many unwise, and the few wise?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And in either case you name them in reference to something?

p.#text: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you call a man wise who knows how to give advice, without knowing whether and when it is better to act upon it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor, I conceive, a man who knows what war is in itself, without knowing when or for how long a time it is better to make war?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor, again, a man who knows how to kill another, or seize his property, or make him an exile from his native land, without knowing when or to whom it is better so to behave?

p.#text: No, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is a man who knows something of this sort, and is assisted by knowledge of what is best,and this is surely the same as knowledge of the useful, is it not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we shall call him wise, and a competent adviser both of the city and of his own self;  but a man not so qualified we shall call the opposite of these.  How do you think?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

p.#text:
And what of a man who knows how to ride or shoot, or else to box or wrestle or contend in any other sport,
or do anything that we know by rule of art?  What do you call him who knows what is better done by rule of that particular art?  Do you not say that he who goes by the rules of riding is a good rider?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

note.#text: occurs, with the genitive, in ;  the normal Platonic phrase for our passage is .

p.#text: And the rules of boxing, I suppose, make a good boxer, and those of flute-playing a good flute-player, and so, on the same lines, I presume, with the rest;  or is there any difference?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, it is as you say.

p.#text:
Then do you think it inevitable that he who has some knowledge about these things should also be a wise man,
or shall we say he comes far short of it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Far short of it, I declare.

p.#text:
Then what sort of state do you suppose it would be, where the people were good bowmen and flute-players, together with athletes and artists in general, and mingled with these the men whom we have just mentioned as knowing war in itself and slaughter in itself, and orator-windbags too with their political bluster, but all of them lacked this knowledge of the best, and none knew when or upon whom it was better
to employ their respective arts?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: A paltry one, I should call it, Socrates.

l.#text: Wherein himself is found most excellent,

note.#text: Cf. .

p.#text:
Yes, you would, I expect, when you saw each one of them vying with the other and assigning the largest part in the conduct of the state to that I mean, what is done best by rule of his particular artwhile he is entirely off the track of what is best for the state and for himself, because, I conceive, he has put his trust in opinion apart from intelligence.  In these circumstances,
should we not be right in saying that such a state is one great mass of turmoil and lawlessness?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We should, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we took it to be necessary that we should first think we know, or really know, anything that we confidently intend either to do or to say?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We did.

p.#text:
And if a man does what he knows or thinks he knows, and is assisted by knowing how to make it beneficial, we shall find him profitable
both to the city and to himself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if, I suppose, he does the contrary, he will not be so either to the city or to himself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, do you still take the same view now as before, or do you think differently?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I take the same view.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you said you called the many unwise, and the few wise?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I did.

p.#text: So now we repeat our statement that the many have missed getting the best because in most cases, I conceive, they have put their trust in opinion apart from intelligence.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is an advantage to the many neither to know nor to think they know anything, if they are going to be specially eager to do what they know or think they know, but are likely on the whole, in doing it, to be injured rather than benefited.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is very true.

p.#text:
So you see that when I said it looked as though
the possession of the sciences as a whole, where it did not include the science of the best, in a few cases helped, but in most harmed the owner, I was evidently right in very truth, was I not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Though I did not then, I think so now, Socrates.

l.#text: Full many crafts he knew:  but still

l: He knew them all so very ill.

note.title: Margites
note.#text: Quoted from the mock-epic , of which only this and five other lines have survived.  The hero, Margites, became the proverbial type of a blundering idiot, and the poem was generally attributed to Homer.

p.#text:
Hence the state or soul that is to live aright must hold fast to this knowledge, exactly as a sick man does to a doctor, or as he who would voyage safely does to a pilot.  For without this,
the more briskly it is wafted by fortune either to the acquisition of wealth or to bodily strength or aught else of the sort, the greater will be the mistakes in which these things, it would seem, must needs involve it.  And he who has acquired the so-called mastery of learning and arts, but is destitute of this knowledge and impelled by this or that one among those others, is sure to meet with much rough weather, as he truly deserves;  since, I imagine, he must continue without a pilot on the high seas, and has only the brief span of his life in which to run his course. 
So that his case aptly fits the saying of the poet, in which he complains of somebody or other that

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, how on earth is the poet's saying apposite, Socrates?  For to my mind it has nothing to do with the point.

note.#text: This trick of twisting the words of a quotation into an unnatural meaning is quite characteristic of Socrates.  Cf.  .

p.#text:
It is very much to the point:  but he, good sir, like almost every other poet, speaks in riddles.  For poetry as a whole is by nature
inclined to riddling, and it is not every man who can apprehend it.  And furthermore, besides having this natural tendency, when it gets hold of a grudging person who wishes not to show forth to us his own wisdom but to conceal it as much as possible, we find it an extraordinarily difficult matter to make out whatever this or that one of them may mean.  For surely you do not suppose that Homer, divinest and wisest of poets, did not know it was impossible to know ill;  for it is he who says of Margites that he knew many things,
but knew them all ill:  but it is a riddle, I think, in which he has made ill stand for evil, and knew for to know.  So if we put it together, letting the meter go, indeed, but grasping his meaning, we get this:  Full many crafts he knew, but it was evil for him to know them all. Then clearly, if it was evil for him to know many things, he was in fact a paltry fellow, assuming we are to believe what we have previously argued.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But I think we may, Socrates:  at least, if I cannot believe those arguments of ours, I shall find it hard to trust any others.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you are right in so thinking.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I repeat that I think so.

p.#text:
But come now, in Heaven's namefor I suppose you see how great and strange is our perplexity, in which you, as it seems to me, have your share;  for you change about from this side to that without settling down for a moment, but as soon as you are firmly convinced of a thing you seem to slip out of it again and
cease to hold the same viewwell, if the god to whom you are going should even now appear to you and ask before you uttered any prayer, whether you would be content to obtain one of those things which were mentioned at the beginning, or whether he should leave you to pray as you were, how do you suppose you would make the best of your chanceby accepting his offer, or by praying for something on your own account?

note.#text: i.e., that I should answer offhand.  The pun in , , alluding to the fatuous Margites, cannot be rendered in English.

p.#text:
Well, by the gods, I could not answer your question, Socrates, offhand.  Why, I take it to be a fatuous request,
when it is really a case for great caution lest one pray unawares for what is evil while thinking it to be one's good, and then after a little while, as you were saying, one change one's tune and retract all one's former prayers.
And did not the poet whom I quoted at the beginning of our discussion know more than we, when he bade us pray for the averting of what is grievous, even though we pray for it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think so.

l.#text: Sacrificed to the immortals perfect hecatombs,
But the blessed gods partook not of it, nor would have it,
For deep was their hate against holy ,
And Priam, and the folk of Priam of the good ashen spear.

p.#text:
Then it is their admiration of this poet, Alcibiades,
or perhaps the result of their own study, that causes the Spartans to offer a similar prayer whether the occasion be private or publicthat the gods will give them for their own benefit the beautiful as well as the good:  more than this no one can ever hear them pray for.  The consequence is that to the present time they have been just as fortunate as any other people;  and if it has befallen them to be not invariably fortunate, it was anyhow not owing to their prayer. 
It rests with the gods, I conceive, to give us either what we may pray for or the reverse. And I would like to give you an account of something else, which I once heard from some of my seniors.  A quarrel having arisen between the Athenians and the Spartans, it befell our city to be always unsuccessful in every battle by land and sea, and she could never win a victory.  So the Athenians, in their annoyance at this result, and at a loss for some means of finding a deliverance from the trouble they were in,
took counsel together and decided that the best thing they could do was to send and inquire of Ammon;  and moreover, to ask also for what reason the gods granted victory to the Spartans rather than to themselves:  for wesuch was the message offer up to them more and finer sacrifices than any of the Greeks, and have adorned their temples with votive emblems as no other people have done, and presented to the gods the costliest and stateliest processions year by year, and spent more money thus than
all the rest of the Greeks together.  But the Spartans have never taken any such pains, and indeed are so neglectful in their behavior to the gods, that they make a practice of sacrificing defective victims, and generally are very much behind us in the honors that they pay, though the wealth they possess is quite equal to that of our city. When they had so spoken, and added the question, what they should do in order to find a deliverance from the trouble they were in,
the prophet's only answer  evidently it was all that the god allowedwas to call them to him and say:  Thus saith Ammon to the Athenians:  I would rather have the reverent reserve of the Spartans than all the ritual of the Greeks. So much he said, and not a word further.  Now by reverent reserve I suppose the god could only mean their prayer, since in fact it differs greatly from those that are generally offered. 
For the Greeks in general either lead up bulls with gilded horns, or else present the gods with votive emblems, and pray for any odd thing, whether it be good or bad:  so when the gods hear their irreverent speech they reject all these costly processions and sacrifices.  Whereas I think we ought to be very cautious, and fully consider what is to be said and what is not. And in Homer too you will find other tales of a similar sort.  For he relates how the Trojans,
    in making their bivouac,and how the winds bore the sweet savour from the plain into heaven:
So it was nothing to their purpose to sacrifice and pay tribute of gifts in vain, when they were hated by the gods.  For it is not, I imagine, the way of the gods to be seduced with gifts, like a base insurer.  And indeed it is but silly talk of ours, if we claim to surpass the Spartans on this score.  For it would be a strange thing if the gods had regard to our gifts and sacrifices instead of our souls, and the piety and
justice that may be found in any of us.  Far rather at these, I believe, do they look than at those costly processions and sacrifices which are offered, it well may be, by individual and state, year in, year out, though they may have offended greatly against the gods, or as greatly against their neighbors.  But the gods are not to be won by bribes, and so they despise all these things, as Ammon and the holy prophet say.  Certainly it would seem that justice and wisdom are held in especial honor both by the gods and by men of intelligence; 
and wise and just are they alone who know what acts and words to use towards gods and men.  But I should like now to hear what may be your opinion on the subject.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, Socrates, it in no wise differs from yours and the god's;  for indeed it would not be fitting for me to record my vote against the god.

p.#text:
And you remember you professed to be in great perplexity lest you should pray unawares for evil,
while supposing it to be good?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

note.#text: Cf. .

p.#text:
You see, then, how unsafe it is for you to approach the god with your prayers, for it may chance that when he hears your irreverent speech he will reject your sacrifice altogether, and you may perhaps be accorded some other bad thing as well.  In my opinion, therefore, it is best to hold your peace:  for I expect you will not consent to use the Spartan's prayer, you have such a romantic spiritto give it the fairest of folly's names.
    It is necessary, therefore, to bide one's time until one can learn how one should behave towards gods and men.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, when will that time arrive, Socrates, and who is to be my instructor?  For I feel I should very much like to see who the man is,

l.#text: That be might well discern both god and man,

p.#text:
It is he who is concerned about you.  But I think, as Homer relates how Athena removed the mist from the eyes of Diomede,
so you too must first have the mist removed which now enwraps your soul, and then you will be ready to receive the means whereby you will discern both evil and good.  For at present I do not think you could do so.

Let him remove the mist or whatever else he likes to call it:  for I am prepared to obey every one of his commands, without shirking, whoever the man may be, so long as I am to be the better for them.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I tell you, he on his part is prodigiously anxious to help you.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Then I think it best to defer the sacrifice also till the time comes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you are quite right:  for that is safer than running so serious a risk.

p.#text:
But how say you, Socrates?  Look now, I will crown you with this garland, as I consider you have given me such good advice;  and to the gods
    we shall offer both garlands and all the other customary things when I see that day has come.  And come it will ere long, if they are willing.

note.#text: The Greek here is literallyI should gladly see myself to have acceptedwhich seems very unplatonic.

The blind prophet Teiresias has been crowned by the Athenians for the aid he has given them in a successful war.  Eteocles, the young king of , has left the city in charge of his uncle Creon while he is fighting his brother Polynices for the possession of the throne.

l.#text: As omen good I take thy victor's wreaths;

l: For in the waves we labour, as you know,

p.#text:
Well, I accept this gift;  and anything else besides, that you may give me, I shall be only too happy to accept. And as Euripides has made Creon say when he sees Teiresias wearing his wreaths, and hears that he has obtained them, on account of his art, as first-fruits of the spoils of war:
so do I take this opinion of yours as a good omen.  For I consider I am no less wave-tossed than Creon, and would like to come off victorious over your lovers.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what is love of gain?  What can it be, and who are the lovers of gain?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: In my opinion, they are those who think it worth while to make gain out of things of no worth.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is it your opinion that they know those things to be of no worth, or do not know?  For if they do not know, you mean that the lovers of gain are fools.

p.#text:
No, I do not mean they are fools, but rascals who wickedly yield to gain, because they know that the things out of which they dare to make their gain are worthless,
and yet they dare to be lovers of gain from mere shamelessness.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, do you mean by the lover of gain such a man, for instance, as a farmer who plants something which he knows is a worthless herb, and thinks fit to make gain out of it when he has reared it up?  Is that the sort of man you mean?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: The lover of gain, as such, Socrates, thinks he ought to make gain from everything.

p.#text:
Please do not speak so recklessly, as though you had been wronged by someone,
but give me your attention and answer just as you would if I were beginning my questions over again.  Do you not admit that the lover of gain has knowledge of the worth of the thing from which he thinks it worth while to make gain?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I do.

note.#text: The artful phrase here is the jingling , characteristic of the rhetoric taught by Gorgias and his followers.

p.#text: Then who has knowledge of the worth of plants, and of the sort of season and soil in which they are worth plantingif we too may throw in one of those artful phrases which adroit pleaders use to trick out their speeches in the law courts?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: For my part, I should say a farmer.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And by think it worth while to make gain do you mean aught but thinking one ought to make gain?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I mean that.

p.#text:
Then do not attempt to deceive me, who am now quite an elderly person,
and you so young, by making, as you did just now, an answer that is not even your own thought;  but tell me in all truth, do you suppose that any man who was taking up farming and who knew it was a worthless plant that he was planting, could think to make gain from it?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Upon my word, I do not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Or again, take a horseman who knows that he is providing worthless food for his horse;  do you suppose he is unaware that he is destroying his horse?

p.#text: I do not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So he does not think to make gain from that worthless food.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Or again, take a navigator who has furnished his ship with worthless spars and ropes;  do you think he is unaware that he will suffer for it, and will be in danger of being lost himself, and of losing the ship and all her cargo?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I do not.

p.#text:
So he does not think to make gain from
that worthless tackle?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But does a general, who knows that his army has worthless arms, think to make gain, or think it worth while to make gain, from them?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: By no means.

p.#text: Or does a flute-player who has worthless flutes, or a harper with a lyre, a bowman with a bow, or anyone else at all, in short, among ordinary craftsmen or sensible men in general, with any implement or other equipment of any sort that is worthless, think to make gain from it?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: To all appearance, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then whoever can they be, your lovers of gain?  For I presume they are not the people whom we have successively mentioned, but people who know their worthless things, and yet think they are to make gain from them.  But in that case, by what you say, remarkable sir, no man alive is a lover of gain

p.#text:
Well, Socrates, I should like to call those lovers of gain who from insatiable greed consumedly long for things that are even quite petty and of little or no worth,
and so love gain, in each case.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Not knowing, of course, my excellent friend, that the things are worthless;  for we have already convinced ourselves by our argument that this is impossible.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if not knowing this, clearly they are ignorant of it, but think that those worthless things are worth a great deal.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now, of course lovers of gain must love gain?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

p.#text: And by gain you mean the opposite of loss?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is it a good thing for anyone to suffer loss?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: For no one.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Rather an evil?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So mankind are harmed by loss.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: They are harmed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then loss is an evil.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And gain is the opposite of loss.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: The opposite.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So that gain is a good.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence it is those who love the good that you call lovers of gain.

p.#text: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: At least there is nothing mad, my friend, about lovers of gain, as you describe them.  But tell me, do you yourself love, or not love, whatever is good?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I love it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is there anything good that you do not love, or must it then be evil?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Upon my word, nothing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In fact, I expect you love all good things.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

p.#text:
Well now, ask me on my side whether I do not likewise:  for I shall agree with you, for my part, that I love good things.  But besides you and me, do you not think that all the rest of mankind
love good things, and hate evil things?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: It appears so to me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we admitted that gain is good?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: On this new showing, everyone appears to be a lover of gain;  whereas, by our former way of arguing, no one was a lover of gain.  So on which of the two arguments are we to rely, in order to avoid error?

p.#text:
What has to be done, I think, Socrates, is to conceive the lover of gain rightly.  The right view of the lover of gain is that he is one who concerns himself with,
and thinks fit to make gain from, things from which honest men do not dare to make gain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you see, my sweet sir, we have just admitted that making gain is being benefited.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Well, what of that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There is the further point we have admitted in addition to thisthat all men wish for good things always.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

p.#text: Then good men likewise wish to have all gains, if these are good things.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Not those gains from which they are bound, Socrates, to suffer harm.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: By suffer harm do you mean suffer loss, or something else?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: No, I mean just suffer loss.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, do men suffer loss from gain or from loss?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: From both;  for they suffer loss from loss and from wicked gain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Pray now, do you consider that any useful and good thing is wicked?

p.#text: I do not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we admitted a little while ago that gain is the opposite of loss, which is an evil.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that, being the opposite of an evil, it is good?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: That was our admission.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you see, you are attempting to deceive me, for you deliberately contradict what we agreed to just now.

p.#text: No, on my honor, Socrates;  on the contrary, it is you who are deceiving me, by twisting this way and that so perplexingly in your talk.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hush, hush!  Why, surely it would be wrong of me not to obey a good and wise person.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Who is that?  And to what are you referring now?

l.#text: The memorial of Hipparchus:  walk with just intent.
The memorial of Hipparchus:  deceive not a friend.

note.#text: A town on the south-east coast of .
On this point the writer agrees with , who gives what is now the accepted story of Harmodius and Aristogeiton.
In the Panathenaic procession.

This curious version of the fall of the Pisistratid rulers (Hippias and Hipparchus) seeks to explain the conspiracy as due to a rivalry in a sort of pre-Socratic influence over young men which arose between the citizen Aristogiton and the ruler Hipparchus.

p.#text:
I mean my and your fellow-citizen, Pisistratus's son Hipparchus, of Philaidae, who was the eldest and wisest of Pisistratus's sons, and who, among the many goodly proofs of wisdom that he showed, first brought the poems of Homer into this country of ours, and compelled the rhapsodes at the Panathenaea to recite them in relay, one man following on another, as
they still do now.  He dispatched a fifty-oared galley for Anacreon of , and brought him into our city.  Simonides of  he always had about him, prevailing on him by plenteous fees and gifts.  All this he did from a wish to educate the citizens, in order that he might have subjects of the highest excellence;  for he thought it not right to grudge wisdom to any, so noble and good was he.  And when his people in the city had been educated and were admiring him for his wisdom,
he proceeded next, with the design of educating those of the countryside, to set up figures of Hermes for them along the roads in the midst of the city and every district town;  and then, after selecting from his own wise lore, both learnt from others and discovered for himself, the things that he considered the wisest, he threw these into elegiac form and inscribed them on the figures as verses of his own and testimonies of his wisdom, so that in the first place
his people should not admire those wise Delphic legends of  and , and the other sayings of the sort, but should rather regard as wise the utterances of Hipparchus;  and that in the second place, through passing up and down and reading his words and acquiring a taste for his wisdom, they might resort hither from the country for the completion of their education.  There are two such inscriptions of his:  on the left side
of each Hermes there is one in which the god says that he stands in the midst of the city or the township, while on the right side he says:There are many other fine inscriptions from his poems on other figures of Hermes, and this one in particular, on the Steiria road, in which he says:
I therefore should never dare, I am sure, to deceive you, who are my friend, or disobey the great Hipparchus, after whose death the Athenians were for three years under the despotic rule of his brother Hippias, and you might have heard anyone of the earlier period say that it was only in these years that there was despotism in , and that at all other times the Athenians lived very much as in the reign of Cronos.  And the subtler sort of people say
that Hipparchus's death was due, not to the cause supposed by mostthe disqualification of the assassin's sister from bearing the basket, for that is a silly motivebut because Harmodius had become the favorite of Aristogeiton and had been educated by him.  Thus Aristogeiton also prided himself on educating people, and he regarded Hipparchus as a dangerous rival.  And at that time, it is said, Harmodius
happened to be himself in love with one of the handsome and well-born youths of the day;  they do tell his name, but I cannot remember it.  Well, for a while this youth admired both Harmodius and Aristogeiton as wise men, but afterwards, when he associated with Hipparchus, he despised them, and they were so overcome with the pain of this disqualification that they slew Hipparchus.

It would seem, then, Socrates, either that you do not regard me as your friend, or if you do, that you do not obey Hipparchus. 
For that you are not deceiving methough I cannot tell how you contrive itin your talk, is more than I can believe.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, as though we were playing draughts, I am willing to let you revoke, as you please, anything you have said in carrying on the discussion, in order that you may not think you are being deceived.  So tell me, shall I revoke for you the statement that all men desire good things?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: No, thank you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, that suffering loss, or loss, is an evil?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: No, thank you.

p.#text: Well, that gain, or making gain, is the opposite of loss, or suffering loss?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Nor that either.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, that making gain, as the opposite of evil, is a good?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Nothing of all this do I bid you revoke for me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You think, then, it seems, that some gain is good, and some evil.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, I revoke so much for you;  so let us assume that some gain is good, and some other gain evil.  But the good sort is no more gain than the evil sort, is it?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: What do you mean by this question?

p.#text: I will explain.  Is there both good and evil food?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is the one sort more food than the other, or are they both similarly this same thing, food, and in this respect does the one differ no wise from the other, in being food, but only in the fact of the one being good and the other evil?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

p.#text:
And so with drink and every other class of things that exist, when some things in any class come to be good, and others evil, one thing does not differ from another in that respect whereby they are the same?  For instance,
one man, I suppose, is virtuous, and another wicked.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But neither of them, I conceive, is more or less man than the otherneither the virtuous than the wicked, nor the wicked than the virtuous.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: What you say is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then are we to take the same view of gain also, that both the wicked and the virtuous sort are similarly gain?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Necessarily.

p.#text:
So he who has virtuous gain is no whit the more a gainer than he who has wicked gain:  neither sort
is found to be more gain, as we agree.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For neither of them has addition of either more or less.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how could one do or suffer anything more or less with a thing of this sort, that had neither of these additions?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Impossible.

p.#text:
Since, therefore, both of these are gains and gain-making affairs, we must now consider what it can be that leads you to call both of them gain: 
what is it that you see to be the same in both?  Suppose you were to ask me, in those instances that I gave just now, what it is that leads me to call both good food and evil food alike food, I should tell you for this reason, because both are a dry sustenance of the body.  For that, I am sure you would agree, is what food is, would you not?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I would.

p.#text:
And so too about drink the answer would be on the same lines, that the wet sustenance of the body,
whether it be wholesome or pernicious, has this name of drink;  and likewise with the rest.  Try therefore on your part to imitate my method of answering.  When you say that virtuous gain and wicked gain are both gain, what is it that you see to be the same in them, judging it to be the actual element of gain?  And if again you are yourself unable to answer, just let me put it for your consideration, whether you describe as gain every acquisition that one has acquired either with no expense, or as a profit over and above one's expense.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I believe that is what I call gain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you include a case where, after enjoying a banquet at which one has had much good cheer without any expense, one acquires an illness?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Upon my word, not I.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if one acquired health from attending a banquet, would one acquire gain or loss?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Gain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence gain is not just acquiring any acquisition.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you mean, not if it is evil?  Or will one acquire no gain even if one acquires something good?

p.#text: Apparently one will, if it is good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if it is evil, will not one acquire loss?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You see, then, how you are running round again to the same old point?  Gain is found to be good, and loss evil.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: For my part, I cannot tell what to say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And not without good reason, sir.  Now answer this further question:  you say that if one acquires more than the amount one has spent, it is gain?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I do not mean, when it is evil, but if one gets more gold or silver than one has spent.

p.#text:
Now, I am just going to ask you about that.  Tell me,
if one spends half a pound of gold and gets double that weight in silver, has one got gain or loss?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Loss, I presume, Socrates for one's gold is reduced to twice, instead of twelve times, the value of silver.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you see, one has got more;  or is double not more than half?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Not in worth, the one being silver and the other gold.

p.#text: So gain, it seems, must have this addition of worth.  At least, you now say that silver, though more than gold, is not worth as much, and that gold, though less, is of equal worth.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Assuredly, for that is the case.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the valuable is what produces gain, whether it be small or great, and the valueless produces no gain.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And by the valuable you mean simply, valuable to possess?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes, to possess.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again, by what is valuable to possess, do you mean the unprofitable or the profitable?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: The profitable, I presume.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the profitable is good?

p.#text: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so, most valiant of men, have we not here once more, for the third or fourth time, the admission that what produces gain is good?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you remember the point from which this discussion of ours arose?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I think I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In case you do not, I will remind you.  You maintained against me that good men do not wish to make all sorts of gain, but only those gains that are good, and not those that are wicked.

p.#text: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And now the argument has compelled us to acknowledge that all gains, both small and great, are good?

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes, it has compelled me, at least, Socrates, rather than persuaded me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, later on, perhaps, it might also persuade you.  Now, however, whether you are persuaded or whatever is your feeling, you at least agree with me that all gains are good, both small and great ones.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Yes, I do admit it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you admit that virtuous men all wish for all good things, do you not?

p.#text: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, you know, you stated yourself that wicked men love both small and great gains.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so, by your account, all men will be lovers of gain, whether they be virtuous or wicked.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence it is not right to reproach anybody with being a lover of gain:  for he who makes this reproach is actually such an one himself.
